title: Student faces deportation from UK after arriving early for course at university’s request

last_post.content:
Something like this happened to me too, years ago, when I was pursuing postgraduate studies in the UK. The way that the bureaucratic apparatuses of the UK treated me has really negatively influenced my desire to visit, do business with, or lend my expertise to this country, and I can't help but wonder how they treat people who look different from me and Rasikh...

title: Trump Wanted to Hire Laura Loomer, Anti-Muslim Activist

last_post.content:
New report that Donald Trump wanted to add racist grifter Laura Loomer to his campaign for the White House in 2024.

Loomer has extensive connections to neo-Nazis and white supremacists. During her failed bid for a congressional seat in Florida, she was supported by then ally, Milo Yiannopoulos, when then went on to work with Nick Fuentes and Kanye West.

Loomer was also a recent speaker at the white supremacist, "American Renaissance" conference, known for hosting such neo-Nazis as Richard Spencer, Nick Fuentes, and David Duke.

#Trump #Trump2024 #MAGA

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/07/us/politics/trump-laura-loomer.html

Academic Youtuber
Andy Stapleton gets exasperated waiting for AI tools to answer questions about academic research. But the real culprit isn't ChatGPT, it's the PDFs he feeds to the tools, which are a horror to parse.

Gotta admit I didn't realize this upside to the inscrutability of PDFs: they resist being harvested by AI 🤷‍♂️

https://youtu.be/smWlQ5u-0Jc

10/ Turning back to the present, Denmark 🇩🇰 is part of the European Union 🇪🇺, but the Faroe Islands 🇫🇴 and Greenland 🇬🇱 are not.

Denmark is however unique amongst EU countries in that it does not have to adopt the Euro 💶 as its currency

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denmark_and_the_euro

7/ Denmark 🇩🇰 includes the island of Bornholm, farther east in the Baltic. It is closer to Sweden 🇸🇪, Germany 🇩🇪, and Poland 🇵🇱 than the rest of Denmark, and was briefly occupied by the Soviets at the end of of WWII

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bornholm

#geoweirdness

6/ One could also argue Denmark 🇩🇰 added a land border with Sweden 🇸🇪 with the completion of the Øresund Bridge in 2000, connecting Copenhagen and Malmö across the Øresund strait

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge

#geoweirdness

5/ 🇩🇰 Denmark's other land border is with 🇩🇪 Germany, and was set via plebiscite in 1920 thus finally resolving "the Schleswig-Holstein question", a repeated source of conflict in 19th century

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schleswig%E2%80%93Holstein_question

Today there is an officially recognised German-speaking minority in Denmark, and an equivalent Danish-speaking minority in Germany:

title: GitHub - grantmcdermott/plot2: Lightweight extension of base R's plot function

last_post.content:
We all love ggplot2 (obvs), but base R plot is underrated IMO.

I finally packaged up a script I've had lying around for a while. The `plot2` #rstats 📦 is a lightweight extension to base R plot that automates grouped plotting and legend handling (plus some extras). https://github.com/grantmcdermott/plot2

4/ As we covered in our Canada 🇨🇦 thread a month ago, last year we had the exciting news that Canada and the Kingdom of Denmark 🇩🇰 resolved their dispute over remote Hans Island, ending the "Whisky War" in which the armies of each country left bottle of alcohol for each other.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whisky_War

As a result, Greenland 🇬🇱 now shares a land border with Canada.

title: Burj Al Babas: Inside an Abandoned Town of Disney-esque Castles

last_post.content: ❝ With many of the villas started but not one finished, the town remains unlivable. From afar, the gray-roofed neighborhood looks like something out of a Disney movie but, upon closer inspection, Burj Al Babas boasts an eerie postapocalyptic feel with rows of partially completed castles, patchy landscaping, and zero signs of life. The empty village is chilling, to say the least—like a sparkling city ravaged by war. ❞ → https://www.architecturaldigest.com/gallery/burj-al-babas
https://yewtu.be/amhINnExdJE

The reason your ML professor keeps prattling on about data leakage and insisting you set aside a test set and use it *only* for validation, making sure that at validation time the data on which you predict is entirely novel for the model, is not merely that she's a stuck-up, inflexible bore. It's also because publishing and subsequently debunking papers that don't do that is a colossal waste of resources. Thank you for your work, @kordinglab https://neuromatch.social/@kordinglab/110155049278014769

title: Giving up Twitter, and the impact on my business - Neil Brown

last_post.content:
Giving up Twitter, and the impact on my business.

A rather long-winded, rambling #BlogPost, in which I try to jot down some of my thoughts about the impact of my choice to leave Twitter, and to spend more time in the fediverse, from the point of view of getting new clients (I'm a solicitor).

For me, so far, the fediverse is definitely on par with Twitter from this point of view.

title: Add chatty-pgp (!1208) · Merge requests · Librem5 / chatty · GitLab

last_post.content:
I've been playing around a lot with PGP since I have an openPGP card in my phone.

I made a backend to have my PGP card sign and encrypt messages in Chatty, the hope being that I can add transparent encryption/signing to SMS/MMS and the other protocols Chatty supports:
https://source.puri.sm/Librem5/chatty/-/merge_requests/1208

What's left now is to work on the UI to have friendly user integration.

title: Twitter has outsized influence, but it doesn’t drive much traffic for most news orgs, a new report says

last_post.content:
I think people need to understand that Twitter is not a major driver of traffic for most news organizations.

The reason why news organizations are on twitter is because reporters and editors are on it, and it's useful as a tool to get in touch with certain types of folks.

News orgs can leave twitter because it's not critical for them.

(see https://www.niemanlab.org/2016/04/twitter-has-outsized-influence-but-it-doesnt-drive-much-traffic-for-most-news-orgs-a-new-report-says/ )

Reading this: Eight Things to Know about Large Language Models

1. LLMs predictably get more capable with increasing investment, even without targeted innovation.
2. Many important LLM behaviors emerge unpredictably as a byproduct of increasing investment.
3. LLMs often appear to learn and use representations of the outside world.
4. There are no reliable techniques for steering the behavior of LLMs.
5. Experts are not yet able to interpret the inner workings of LLMs.
6. Human performance on a task isn't an upper bound on LLM performance.
7. LLMs need not express the values of their creators nor the values encoded in web text.
8. Brief interactions with LLMs are often misleading.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00612

@timbray COISMS: Me joking that it probably won't fly as an acronym for independent community-owned social media site.

Redirection: I mean from @tbray@hachyderm.io to @tbray@cosocial.ca.

Context: https://social.coop/@judell/110150414886839046

As things stand, with redirection on, I can't query my mastodon.social and social.coop accounts concurrently, as I was doing before the redirect and as I would still like to be able to do.

Not a big deal but I haven't seen much written about this and am curious.

1. After 40 years of research into what makes remote work succeed …
2. … the pandemic era was a parade of catastrophic “worst hits”!
3. But our workplaces are broken, so workers don’t want to go “back”

title: How Paris Pulled Off What New York and London Can Only Dream About

last_post.content:
When I lived in #Paris in the 1990s, it was a paradise for drivers, hell for cyclists and pedestrians.

Over the years, I've seen it become more like #Amsterdam and #Copenhagen

Henry Grabar explains how they pulled it off...

"How Paris Kicked Out the Cars
A city once remade for voitures has transformed itself into an unlikely utopia for cyclists and pedestrians. What can it teach us?"

title: #599 – An Interview with Uri Shaked (Wokwi.com) | The Amp Hour Electronics Podcast

last_post.content: Listened to the details on the Amp Hour podcast: https://theamphour.com/599-an-interview-with-uri-shaked-wokwi-com/

This blows my mind, Uri Shaked (https://github.com/urish) has written a complete microcontroller simulation for microcontrollers like #arduino and #esp32 that runs entirely in the browser! It simulates every clock cycle, and has to include things like mapping LED PWM to a much lower frame rate display, Wifi modules and other hardware. Pretty wild.

An example: https://wokwi.com/projects/318864638990090834

title: SoK: On the Impossible Security of Very Large Foundation Models

last_post.content:
On the large AI models, this preprint synthesises what we know so far https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15259

In short: it is mathematically impossible to have AIs combining the following properties:

1) High number of parameters
2) Robustness to poisoning (e.g. fake data)
3) Privacy-preserving

#Fedimeister is a #Java based #Mastodon client (available for #Linux, #Windows and #MacOS under the Apache #opensource license) with a focus on #writing and #journalism. Features:

* Break long texts into threads
* Scheduled posting
* Hashtag research
* #Twitter quote tweeting emulation
